Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Leucine Aminopeptidase - Regulator of the Stress-Induced Stromal Proteome
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over 40% of the world's food supply is lost to damage caused by pathogens, pests and weeds. Therefore, novel strategies to enhance plant productivity and resistance to pests will significantly increase the security of the world's food supply. To achieve this goal, a deep understanding the mechanisms that control resistance to insects is needed. This project is at the cutting edge of plant-insect interactions and will reveal how chloroplasts communicate with nuclei to coordinate a robust defense after injury and insect attack; this knowledge will enable new strategies for insect resistance in the future. This project is a fertile training ground for a graduate student. Graduate student leadership skills will be developed through guiding undergraduate's in this project. UCR is a minority-serving institution and this project will recruit and engage students with diverse backgrounds. Results from the project will be disseminated by publications in scientific journals, lay talks to Riverside K-12 schools and the public, and talks at meetings and universities.

This project will study the importance of a tomato chloroplast-localized protein called leucine aminopeptidase (LAP-A) and its role in generating a signal that controls nuclear gene expression after insect feeding and wounding. This project will identify the LAP-A-dependent signal that mediates this chloroplast-to-nucleus communication. The protein/peptide (target) that LAP-A acts on will be identified and the target may be the signal or may create the signal. LAP-A has two activities. LAP-A is an aminopeptidase and may produce the signal by modifying the N-terminus of a target protein/peptide that resides in the chloroplast. LAP-A is also a molecular chaperone and may help targets stay in an active folded state. These activities should influence the target's structure, activity and/or stability and thereby signal production. This project will use cutting-edge proteomics technologies to measure proteins/peptides in three tomato lines that express different levels of LAP-A (LapA-silenced, LapA-overexpressing, and wild type). Aim 1 will identify chloroplast proteins that are (1) cut by LAP-A and (2) have altered stability that is strictly correlated with the presence/absence of LAP-A. Aim 2 will determine the LAP-A-dependent changes in a small peptide called glutathione (GSH). Preliminary data link LAP-A and GSH turnover. GSH is an excellent candidate for the signal as it regulates two defense signals (reactive oxygen species and redox status) in other systems. The identity of LAP-A's targets will reveal the nature of the LAP-A-generated signal that mediates chloroplast-nucleus communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: In 2050, the world’s population will exceed 9 billion and 70% more food must be produced to feed this burgeoning population. Over 30% of crops are lost to damage caused by insects, novel strategies to enhance insect resistance will promote global food security. To achieve this goal, a deep understanding the mechanisms that control resistance to insects is needed. This project is at the cutting edge of plant-insect interaction research and has identified novel signals generated by a protein (leucine aminopeptidase; LAP-A) that coordinates the activities of the chloroplast and nucleus to mediate a robust defense to herbivory.

Project Discoveries: A deep understanding the mechanisms that control resistance to insects is critical for the development of insect-resistant crops. LAP-A is a novel defense regulator that controls resistance to insects in tomatoes (Solanum lycopersicum). Transgenic tomatoes that silence (LapA-SI) or over-express LAP-A (LapA-OX) are more susceptible and resistant to insects, respectively.  LAP-A positively modulates the expression of nuclear genes that protect plants from insect pests and negatively regulates a different set of stress-response genes. LAP-A is known to act downstream of the biosynthesis and perception of a key defense regulator jasmonic acid (JA).

     Surprisingly, LAP-A exerts its control of defenses from the chloroplast. The central hypothesis for this project was that LAP-A regulates a chloroplast-derived signal to control nuclear genes in response to herbivory and stress. The major objective of this project was to discover the identity of the mobile signal(s) that mediates chloroplast-to-nucleus communication. To this end, the proteins that interact with LAP-A (LAP-A targets) were identified to enable the discovery of tomato’s LAP-A-dependent mobile signal(s). LAP-A has two biochemical activities. It is an aminopeptidase and a molecular chaperone. As an aminopeptidase, LAP-A can produce a signal by hydrolyzing the N-terminus of a chloroplast-localized protein or peptide. This modified protein or peptide may be the signal or generate the signal within the chloroplast. Alternatively, as a chaperone, LAP-A can stabilize a protein’s structure; this LAP-A interacting protein may be the signal or be essential for creating the mobile signal.

     This project focused on discovery-based experiments that have provided the first insights into the LAP-A targets. We now have testable models for LAP-A’s mechanism of action and how LAP-A targets generate signals that coordinate chloroplast and nucleus communication after insect attack (Fig 1). Given the fact that LAP-A acts on proteins, the LAP-A-dependent changes in tomato’s chloroplast stromal proteome were determined, as this is the compartment where LAP-A resides. Discovery 1: A high-yielding, high-purity method for isolating tomato chloroplasts and soluble proteins was developed. Discovery 2: As a baseline for our studies, the complexity of the chloroplast stromal proteome in wild-type (WT) tomato leaves was determined. We identified over 2148 soluble proteins, many of which are novel. Previous estimates of stromal proteomes are 2-3 fold lower than our study. Discovery 3: The stromal proteome content of WT, LapA-SI and LapA-OX plants in untreated and methyl-JA-treated leaves was determined. Over 65 proteins are genotype and/or treatment dependent. These proteins are likely LAP-A targets. Discovery 4: An 85-step method called TAILS allowed determination of the changes in the N-termini of proteins in WT, LapA-SI and LapA-OX plants (+/- MeJA). These data are currently being analyzed and proteins with different N-termini in LapA-SI vs WT or LapA-OX are likely to be LAP-A targets. Discovery 5: The proteins that bind to LAP-A were determined. Of the 60 chloroplast proteins that bound to LAP-A, two sets of proteins are likely to have a role in generating the mobile, LAP-A-dependent signal. The first set of proteins are implicated in altering hydrogen peroxide production in the chloroplast after leaf damage; hydrogen peroxide is a known mobile signal that mediates chloroplast-to-nucleus communication in high light stress and defense in Arabidopsis. Our discovery changes the current dogma in tomato defense, where hydrogen peroxide was thought to be solely generated by plasma membrane-bound enzymes. Discovery 6: LAP-A binds to three subunits of a major proteolytic complex in the chloroplast called Clp and to other stromal oligopeptidases. Therefore, LAP-A is likely to influence the peptide profile of the stroma. During stress in other organisms, changes in organellar peptide profiles influences nuclear gene expression. Elucidating the peptide composition and potential bioactive peptides in WT, LapA-SI and LapA-OX plants will test this hypothesis.

Broader Impacts: This project supported salary/supplies for three graduate students and three undergraduates. Five women (four Latina) and two men were supported; all but one were first in the family to attend college. Graduate student leadership skills were honed by participation in professional development classes and by guiding undergraduate research. Results from the project have been disseminated by talks to K-12 schools and the public, talks at professional meetings and universities and in UCR classes. Publications in peer-reviewed journals are now being submitted.
